text:
This was a huge success in our house this evening although I did make a few minor changes.  I added diced onion and then covered the baking dish with foil for the first half hour of cooking.  I then removed the foil, drained the liquid and poured the remainder of the sauce over the chops and cooked uncovered for another 20 minutes.  The result was succulent, tender and very tasty with all the family going back for seconds.  Will definitely keep this recipe handy.  Thank you to the original poster.

text:
This is incredibly easy and delicious.  The chops were SO juicy.  I used boneless ones that were 1-1.5 inches thick and they cooked perfectly in 30 mins.  I also substituted teriyaki sauce for soy sauce because I didn't have any and it worked well.  Just a note: I prepared the full recipe for 2 chops and used every bit.  I would double or triple the recipe for 6.

text:
I'm going to do what I don't like to see other people do and tell you all the changes I made while giving this recipe 4 stars!  I replaced the ketchup with chili garlic sauce, replaced the lemon juice with lime juice, and replaced all of the oil with just 1 Tbsp of sesame oil for a doubled sauce recipe.  I also added 2 Tbsp of rice wine vinegar, again for a doubled recipe.  I broiled the pork chops, six minutes per side and reduced the marinade to serve as a sauce.  Everyone, kids included, loved this.  The basic dish was a great jumping off place for us!

text:
This was a very good recipe...easy to make and I already had all the ingredients in the house.  The only thing I would do differently next time is perhaps try to let it actualy marinade for the day so that the flavor actually get into the chop.  This time I increased the oven temp to 375 and decreased the cooking time to about 15 mins each side for a boneless chop (1 inch thick) and then let it sit under the broiler for about 3 mins just to get the sauce to "stick" this variation seemed to work out just great the sauce didn't slide off as other reviewers mentioned and the pork chop was tender and not at all dry.  I will definately try this again!

country:
None
text:
Don't know where the poster for this recipe buys their pork chops, but for six pork chops I ended up quadrupling the recipe and using Rice Wine Vinegar in place of more Oil, to have a proper marinade.

This recipe is also not used as a marinade, it's used as a baste more or less, there's zero time in the instructions outside of cooking where the meat is soaking in the mixture (which is what marinades are!).

4 tbsp. Soy Sauce
4 tbsp. Rice Wine Vinegar
4 tbsp. Lime Juice
4 tbsp. Worcestershire Sauce
6 tbsp. Extra Virgin Olive Oil
6 tbsp. Brown Sugar
6 tbsp. Ketchup
4 clvs. Garlic minced

Thoroughly mixed in tupperware container, added in pork chops, closed and shook thoroughly before going to work. Stopped home on lunch and gave it another thorough shaking. 

Cooked on a raised rack in roasting pan @ 350 for 30 min a side, reduced remainder of marinade in a saucepan and drizzled on pork chops before serving.

text:
My family really enjoyed these chops.  I used boneless pork and didn't trim so next time I will use less oil.  I had also added a pat of butter to the sauce just for extra flavor. I didn't have lemon juice so I used red wine vinegar instead.  When I pulled them from the oven, I kept 1/4 of sauce with the pork chops and made gravy form the 3/4 of the sauce.  It turned out great!  I used the gravy for the chops and rice and served brussel sprouts with the meal.  I almost had the leftovers for breakfast!  But I waited for lunch and it was just as good!

text:
This marinade is delicious and sooo easy!!I tripled ingredients to make marinade for 6 1-inch boneless chops, subbing teriyaki sauce for soy. Mixed marinade in large ziploc, added chops, and threw in fridge about 4 hrs. I poured all into foil-lined baking dish with quartered onion and baked for 20 mins, covered. I then poured off excess liquid, and spooned double batch of sauce on flip side. Baked, uncovered, 15 mins more. I served them with garlic mashed potatoes and creamed peas! Hubby and kids say this one is "for sure a keeper"

text:
I have a family of 7.  Five out of the 7 are children ages ranging from 18-5 yrs and they all love this.  However, I did make changes in the oils.  I used extra virgin olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  I also doubled the recipe.  Cook for the specified time alloted however for the first 30 minutes I keep the chops covered.  The last thirty minutes I add the second batch of sauce (drizzle it on), leave the foil off, and kick the temp up to 425.  This allow things to caramelize.  Great combination on the ingredients.

country:

text:
Yeah!  On my third attempt I was finally able to get some really good results.  First attempt the sauce didn't stick at all, was basically pointless.  Second attempt they were way overcooked.  This time I doubled the recipe for only 4 chops, except for the vegetable oil, which I only increased by 50% after so many people saying they'd gotten good results leaving it out entirely.  I was using boneless chops, put half the sauce on top and cooked covered with foil for 15 minutes.  Took it out, spooned out most of the liquid, put the rest of the sauce on top and cooked uncovered for 10 minutes.  Then broiled for 5 minutes.  Next time I will probably either decrease the oil more or save some sauce to put on it right before the broil to keep more of it intact.  Finally, these were some of the best pork chops I'd eaten, required no added salt or ketchup, which I normally rely on since I don't love pork.

text:
I made this tonight with 3 pork chops (as opposed to 6 in the recipe).  I substituted olive oil for the vegetable oil and tomato sauce for the ketchup.  I also omitted the Worcestershire sauce, because I didn't have any on hand.  In addition, I added a package of sliced fresh mushrooms and a large chopped sweet onion.  Plus overall, I made more marinade than in the recipe (about DOUBLE, in spite of the fact that I used fewer chops), figuring the onion and mushrooms would need marinade - which they did.  The result was delicious, and I enjoyed the added health benefit of the vegetables.  Will definitely make again!

text:
These were great! 
I doubled the recipe for 6 chops and added a tablespoon more brown sugar to make the sauce a little thicker. Cover&cook for 30 minutes, strain pan, flip over chops, brush marinade all over them, cook uncovered for 25 min, and broil the last 5 minutes. PERFECT. 
I also make the marinade when I buy the chops, freeze it WITH the chops, in the same ziploc bag. Just put it in the fridge to defrost over night and bam, marinated pork chops.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor of these chops was good, but there was something a little bit lacking, which I think has more to do with the means of cooking, rather than the marinade itself. Ultimately, I think this marinade would make some fantastic grilled pork chops, but baking it is rather boring. Some other notes: I made the entire marinade recipe for two chops, and wouldn't have wanted any less. Also, actually leaving the chops to marinate for a couple hours(had I had the time) would have given more flavor. The only thing I added in cooking was chopping up 1/2 onion and throwing it on top of the chops after coating them with sauce; I think this was a good addition.

Update: this recipe does work much better as a grill marinade. Grilled, I give it 4 stars, baked, only 3.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Marinated Baked Pork Chops' Haiku: "There's not enough sauce. (And it 'slides' off the chops too.) Directions seem flawed." Surprised to see this called "marinated" when there's no indication of actually marinading the chops. I had 3 nice chops, and I used the entire recipe's amount of ingredients and did marinate them for 2 hrs. Checking on the chops at 30 min. and surprise! They were almost done =/ So I quickly stirred up a 1/2 amount of the recipe again, poured it over them (b/c at this point, the sauce had slipped away and was just pooled in the pan), finished the last of the baking, and took the suggestion of a review to kick it a broil to try to make the sauce stick. Can't say that we were too thrilled w/ the end result, and it's a shame, b/c the chops themselves were thick and beautiful. I'm always happy to try a new recipe out though, since we're usually pork-chop-purists w/ EVOO, S&P.

These were so good. I was very skeptic of this recipe because of the ingredients, ketchup and pork chops didn't sound like a good mix to me, but I used 6 thin bone-in pork chops, and made double of the marinade. I marinated them for 1 hour, covered, and threw into the oven at 400 degrees for half and hour, then i flipped them and cooked for another 20 mins, and then turned the oven up to broil for 5 mins (so the marinade would stick) Fantastic!

One of the nicest porkchop recipes I've seen. Only additions I made were a pinch of garlic powder and I added a peeled and quarted onion in among the chops and basted it with the sauce. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading previous reviews, I made the following changes:  tripled the sauce except that I only used 2 TBSPs of oil, one of which was seseme oil.  I would only use one next time (seseme) b/c there was oil standing on sauce.  I did add about 3 TBSP of rice wine vinegar to make up for using less oil.  I also used 1/2 ketchup and 1/2 chili sauce. 
I cooked 4 chops with half of the sauce for 30 min (covered) then flipped the chops and added the rest of the sauce, covered, and cooked for 20 min.  I then uncovered and put under the broiler for 3 min on each side.  Once it cooled a little the sauce thickened up a bit and it was really good.
I served it with Harvest Rice from this site and green beans.  Would definitely make again!

text:
The cooking time on this recipe is about 45 minutes too long! The oven temp should be higher too. I would say 450. The sauce is strictly a marinade as stated in recipe. Arrowroot or cornstarch to thicken for sauce and heat, but it is lacking flavor depth. Do not overcook pork like your grandmother used to. It should be pink in the middle. Any further cooking will only toughen the meat unless it is stewed to a fall apart texture.

I absolutely LOVED this recipe.  The sauce is what makes it fabulous.  The flavor is so savory and delicious.    I had four 1/2 inch thick pork chops and doubled the ingredients which worked out perfect.  I only cooked 20 mins on one side, 15 on the other and a 5 min broil.  The broil made a big difference. The flavor will keep you wanting more!

text:
I was a little surprised that since the name of the recipe is Marinated Baked Pork Chops it didn't call for you to actually marinate them before cooking! But I followed other reviewers advice and marinated them for about 6 hours in a double bath of the sauce. I used about 1.5 inch thick chops and they were totally done (almost too done) within 20 minutes of cooking. Next time I will reduce the cooking time to 6-7 minutes each side. I made another batch of the sauce and basted them a few times while cooking. Even though they were a little more done than we prefer the flavor was very good. I served them with the Oven-Roasted Potatoes from this website and fresh green beans. Will definitely make again!

text:
I needed a quick recipe one night to jazz up some pork chops.  So I went online and found this recipe.  I had all of the ingredients in the house already which was a bonus!  I double the sauce per other reviews, and used 1/2 inch boneless chops.  After I cooked them for 15 minutes on each side, I was concerned that the sauce was not sticking.  So then I brushed more sauce on them and broiled them for 3 minutes on each side.  It ended up caramelizing the sauce, and they tasted wonderful!  Next time, I will extend the broiling time to 5 minutes on each side.  Thanks for the recipe!

We thought this was a great pork chop recipe.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I did make a few changes.  First, I seasoned the chops with salt and pepper and brown in a bit of oil.  Then I doubled the marinade and poured all of it over the porkchops, and then just flipped them after 30 minutes and cooked for the final 30.  Yummy!

Four stars due to instructions on marinade, cover/uncover, and cook time.

country:

text:
The name is misleading on this one.A marinade needs to sit on the meat awhile prior to cooking to soak its flavor into meat,this is a basted or brushed on sauced pork chop recipe,not marinaded.However if done as a real marinade,allowing juice to sit on meat,make plenty more sauce,the recipe does not make enough sauce. The recipe has errors,but if tweaked some it has a great flavor. Make more sauce for sure,bake the meat shorter tome so it isn't dry,and actually marinade it correctly,let pork sit in juice for at least an hour,if not several hours,to a day.THEN it tastes wonderful,and juicy,and flavor penetrates the pork well.

text:
The sauce and marinade is fantastic and has an Asian flair. I quadrupled the recipe because I wanted plenty. I used 1/2 toasted sesame oil and substituted Heinz chili sauce for 3/4 of the ketchup. Also added 2T sweet Asian chili sauce. I seasoned the chops before marinating with seasoning salt and black pepper. I marinated them for an hour for an hour before cooking. I baked in a cast iron skillet covered with foil for the 1st half hour. I checked the internal temp of the chops and it was already at 195! I still baked for 1/2 hour more and they got more tender. My girlfriend raved. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
These are by far the best pork chops that I have ever tasted. I followed the recipe exactly, except that I didn't use vegetable oil, I used olive oil since that was all I had on hand. I also doubled the recipe, next time I will triple it, it was so yummy. I (accidently) marinated it for 2 days! I put it in the fridge to let it sit in the juice for a couple hours, but we had other dinner plans so it got left in there for 2 days and it tasted delicious. I, like many other reviewers broiled the pork chops after cooking them and it was well worth the wait, so great. The whole family loved them, even the ones who don't usually like pork chops :) Thanks for sharing your great recipe.

country:
None
text:
I added this recipe to my regular line-up years ago and we had it again tonight. It's so easy to make and has a distinctive tangy-sweet flavor. The last couple of times I made it it did not turn out right--way too much liquid in the pan after cooking--but I realized it's probably because they add a 5-10% "solution" to the meat. So this time I just drained all the liquid before adding the remaining sauce and did not have any problem with the finished dish. Also, I cut the amount of oil in half. This is a classic dish you'll go back to again and again.

As the others suggested, I tripled the sauce but I omitted the oil. Let the 3 boneless, thick pork chops marinated for 9 hours. Baked them at 350. After 30 mins., they weren't cooked. Up'd the temp to 425 and cooked them for another 15 mins., turning them over. Then broiled them for 5 mins. My family loved them. The sauce was sweet and poured it over rice. text:
This is very good.  It's similar to my normal 'go-to' pork chop recipe.  However that recipe calls for beer which I didn't have so I decided to try this.  The sauce is awesome and goes great over rice or mashed potatoes.  I used only 3 chops but still made the same amount of sauce and it was perfect.  However I only baked my chops for 30 minutes total.  They were bone-in and about 3/4 inch thick.  They weren't the most tender, but they weren't tough either.  I will definitely use this sauce recipe again but I will either do the chops in the slow cooker or sear them for a couple minutes on each side them simmer them on low in the sauce for about an hour or so.  This always produces very tender chops!

text:
I seasoned the chops with salt, pepper & garlic before adding the sauce.  Didn't have any soy so just skipped it - added a tablespoon of sweet chili sauce for some sweetness.  This has a good flavor but there is way too much vegetable oil in it for my liking, I will cut that down next time and quadruple the sauce because I still could have used more. One hour was too long for the thinner cut boneless chops that I had but it still tasted good. Update 5/2/11 - Used this same arrangement on chicken breasts, letting them marinate for 2 days, it was excellent! I would advise pounding them down a little so the flavor can seep in better. We will use this again. Thank you!

text:
Some of the best pork chops I've made.  I tripled the sauce (except the veg oil which I only upped to 3 Tbsp) and used about 1/2 of it to marinate them for about 8 hours.  I then baked the chops for 30 mins covered, dumped the juice/sauce, flipped the chops and brushed them with more sauce. I cooked for 20 more mins on the second side, then added more sauce and broiled for 2 mins.  Flipped again, added the last of the sauce and broiled for 2 mins on the other side.  They came out perfect- moist, flavorful and juicy.

That and make HUGE batches of the sauce. I use as recommended for 2 chops, and thats stretching it. The other thing I like to do is allow the chops to marinade. Preferably overnight, but at least a few hours...

text:
I would give this recipe 10 stars of I could!  It was sooo good!  I was so worried the pork chops would be dry but that wasn't the case at all - so juicy and tender.  I followed the recipe with no changes except that I doubled the sauce (used 4 boneless pork chops) and sprinkled them with garlic powder first.  I baked them for 20 min covered, flipped them and baked them for 20 more min uncovered.  I broiled them the last 4 or 5 min and they were perfect.  Whenever I make a new recipe, I ask my husband to rate it from 1-10.  He said these were most definitely a 10.  I can't wait to make them again!  Thanks for a great recipe :-)

text:
We liked this recipe as written, then I made it again with a few changes.  My husband isn't fond of soy sauce, so I used an old trick - dilute the soy sauce with water 1:1.  You still get plenty of flavour but cut the salt.  I quadrupled the sauce (but kept the oil to 2 tbsp.), then added 1/2 tsp. oinion powder and 1/4 tsp. garlic powder.  When I asked my husband if he would eat this again, I got an umhm and a nod, but only because his mouth was full.  Thanks so much for the post.  I can hardly wait to try this with chicken, shrimp....

userID:
1488497
Display Name:
mamasama
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1082409.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were excellent!!!  We have 5 kids, so the chances of making something everyone loves is actually quite slim, but these chops had everyone begging for more!  
I followed the others' advice and marinated the chops right in the glass baking pan for 1.5 hrs in the fridge, then set the pan on the counter to warm up while preheating the oven. I just covered it, put the whole thing in the oven for an hour, flipping the chops mid way, and uncovering it for the last 10 mins. and they were soooo tender and flavorful!  I quadrupled the sauce mix and served it on the side and on top for the kiddos to dip in.  I would agree that if you want the sauce to be more like a glaze, a flash broil should do it nicely (if you add more brown sugar, tho, watch it in the oven as the sauce started to get crusty on the edges and would probably burn concidering how sugar behaves). Lastly, as I had no lemon juice or soy sauce on hand, I used a generous amount of lemon pepper seasoning and about a tsp of apple cider vinegar, and a little kikkoman marinade instead of soy.  Excellent dish and thank you!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my very favs.  I put this marinade on pork, chicken & beef, and it tastes awesome on all.  Watch it carefully on the grill though, the sugar in marinade tends to make meat burn very easily.  I tried putting meat and marinade in baking pan, and just putting the whole thing on the grill rack- this worked better, and didn't burn. Try chicken wing dings in this too! Cook wing dings in 13x9 on grill rack until sauce thickens, watch closely at this point, as sauce will go from thick and yummy to burnt and disgusting in minutes. You can't go wrong with this one.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super delicious and easy! I followed the recommendations and doubled the recipe (or more accurately, used the full recipe for only 3 pork chops). I didn't trim the meat and I broiled the pork chops for the last 4 or so minutes and took them out about 5 minutes earlier. I found that timing to be perfect for the thickness of the chops I was working with, they came out very juicy. I made no other adjustments, but next time I will reduce the amount of oil and ketchup. Though the sauce is initially thick, it does thin out when baking. I poured out the extra liquid that had accumulated in the baking dish when I was flipping at the halfway point because I didn't want the meat to steam.

text:
The flavor of the sauce (which is not a marinade) is very good.  However, the recipe makes enough for two 1" chops, no more.  It would probably help to actually marinate them because my two chops were dry and not particularly tender.  I used bone-in chops because I prefer their flavor, but there is nothing extraordinary about these if the recipe is followed.  They will take some doctoring and perhaps covering for while in the oven to meet minimum expectations.

text:
Oh wow!!! We were iced in and I had everything cut up and ready to make pork chops with mushroom gravy (you know the one with cream of mushroom soup) and realized I didn't have any... so I tried this... my 3 year old who doesn't eat much at one time ate 2 and the ones I had were 1.5" thick! The ONLY thing I did different (and only because I already had it cut up) was add mushrooms, garlic and onions.I sauteed them with the second half of the marinade and put that on top for the last 20 minutes. I did dump out most of the stuff from the first half. Also, I strongly suggest at least doubling the recipe! I had 5 1.5" chops (thick but not bone in so kind of small) and I doubled it and had just enough to have some with on rice.

text:
These pork chops were very good and surprisingly tender. Upon the advice of other reviewers, I doubled the quantity of sauce and reserved half of it for basting and for serving. I marinated the chops for 4 hours. It was baked for the first 30 minutes covered with foil. Then, uncovered for an additional 20 minutes, at which time I basted the chops the one time. It gave a beautiful caramelization to the meat. Everyone enjoyed it, even my really picky 7 year old. Thanks for a good recipe!

This is absolutely delicious and has become a staple in our house. I triple the recipe(except for the vegetable oil) and that makes enough sauce to cover the pork and a little left over for those, like my husband, who like tons of sauce. I season my meat with garlic salt and black pepper, pour this sauce over the meat, throw in sliced onions and peeled garlic and it comes out perfect every time.

text:
NOTHING like the recipe had me thinking it would be. To begin with, it was tough as leather. That could be bad cuts from the meat guy. I tenderized it with a meat pounder but no luck. Worse than that is how it had almost no flavor. My friend said it tastes like Spam. I almost agree. The first layer of marinade mix cooked off as soon as I flipped the meat to do the second side. I love pork chops! But I have to say these were the worst, most un-flavorful ones I've ever made and I've been making them 20+ years! Use this recipe at your own risk.

text:
Doubled marinade for 4 chops but used only 1 Tbsp. oil, 1 tsp. cider vinegar in place of lemon juice and added 1 tsp stone ground mustard with horseradish.  Marinated a couple of hours. Drained and reserved juices (to serve over rice) at 30 minutes before coating with remaining sauce, cooked remaining time uncovered.  Very good.  Cook less time if chops are less than one 3/4-1 inch thick.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/614363.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We were very disappointed in this dish.  I scaled it back for two portions -- other than that, I made it exactly as the recipe specified.  For one thing, there was very little sauce.  (If you plan to make this for two people, I'd make the amount of sauce shown here for six people.)  As a result, there wasn't much flavor.  The worst part, however, was how tough the chops were!  I always buy bone-in, THICK-cut pork chops and usually they are very tender and juicy.  These were juicy, but as tough as shoe leather!  I strongly suggest using some sort of meat tenderizer on these, if you plan to make them.  I, for one, will not be making this dish again.

text:
Very tasty and very easy. I used boneless pork chops. It comes out as a bbq type sauce that I'm sure would taste great on chicken too. The only change I made was using canola oil insteal of veg. I also used a little less oil than asked for to make it a bit healthier.  I used a meat thermometer and it was ready in about 40 min rather than the 60min in the recipe. The recipe doesn't make that much sauce, so I recommend doubling it.

text:
Great marinade but I made a few changes. I let the chops marinade for 10 hrs and then cooked at 375 for 45 min covered. Like others suggested, I broiled them for about 5 minutes at the end. I actually had 3 thick boneless chops so I made about triple the amount of sauce, but actually only tripled a few of the ingredients. I kept the ketchup at 2 tbsp, used 3 tbsp of Teriyaki, 1 tsp of oil, 6 tbsp of brown sugar, 2 tbsp of Worcestershire and 2 tbsp of lemon juice. YUMMM!

text:
I've made these twice now, and both times, they were a hit with the family.  I made a few changes last time that made the original recipe even better.  I reduced the oil by half and doubled the remaining marinade ingredients.  I marinated the chops for a few hours in half of the mixture, and basted them with the other half during baking.  At the end of the cooking time, I turned on the broiler to thicken the sauce.  (Otherwise, it will slide off the chops.)

Marinate was easy to prepare and delicious .. I left out the lemon juice only because I didn'thave any on hand but felt after tasting the sauce that there was no need for it. I had used a baking dish as suggested but it prevented the pork chops from browning and marinated to adhear to meat so half way throught the cooking process I replace the baking dish with a cookie sheet. I also turned up the heat of the oven  from 350 to 375 .. which helped in the browning process .. will make again but may go up  a few degrees more on the oven ..

text:
It was okay. I did double the sauce and used sesame oil instead of veg oil. Next time I will only use 2 tbsp oil and double everything else EXCEPT the sugar... it was way too sweet. I added Cayanne and Red Pepper and more acid to balancethe sweetness and it helped but it was too much sugar. I also cooked it covered for 30 minutes then uncovered and broiled 3-4 minutes on each side. It adds a nice glaze and a good crisp to it. I will still add the extra spice next time. I served with rice and squash and it came out decent. I will try this again with the changes I mentioned. Worth trying!

text:
We tried this recipe exactly as written, with exception of cooking time, and found it to be quite bland. I like the base flavors, but next time I will omit most of the oil (it's not needed and it mutes the other flavors), add mustard and some herbs, perhaps rosemary.  Cooking time, in my opinion, is too long for today's pork. I used 1" thick, bone-in chops, and cooked for 40 minutes and let stand for 5.

text:
I wasn't sure how the ingredients were going to marry together but this was acutally quite good - it taste like a thinner, yummier version of BBQ shake and bake.  My modifications:  1.) definitely DOUBLE THE SAUCE.  2.)  I seasoned my chops with salt, pepper and garlic salt and then covered them in the marinade.  3.)  I only baked them for 35 minutes...any longer and they would have been dry and tough.    Definitely a keeper in our house!

The pork chops have great flavor (I love the marinade!), but are quite tough.  Next time, I'll cook them for 30 minutes, max.  There will definitely be a "next time", though!  Thanks for sharing this recipe.

text:
I followed the recipe for the sauce, temperature and time. I used four very thick boneless pork chops - probably 1-1/2 to 2 inches. After one hour, they were done just right. The flavor was good, but not overpowering. One hour was perfect for THICK chops. I think some of the reviewers that reported dry and overcooked were likely using a thinner chop that would cook faster. We did eat with a side of our favorite bbq. sauce to dip bites into. Oh yes, the chops were very moist. I'll be making again - Thanks!

dateLastModified:

userID:
4452392
Display Name:
bellepepper
isPro:
False
followersCount:
535
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
867
favoritesCount:
1863
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/433303.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We grill out almost every night during the summer and last night was no exception.  Although this recipe instructs you to bake the chops, I knew these could be successfully done on the grill.  The sauce was a snap to make, calling for ingredients most everyone would have on hand in their pantry.  I made the full amount of sauce for two huge bone-in chops.  I divided the marinade into three parts.  I marinated the chops in one part.  Hubs used another to baste on while grilling, and lastly, the third part was used to drizzle over the chops at the table.  These came off the grill looking BEAUTIFUL, in fact I would go as far as to say, grilling them enhanced their appearance and flavor, something you wouldnt get if using the oven method.  These were very tasty and something that well definitely be making again and I can see using this marinade/sauce on chicken as well.  Grill or oven, summer or winter, give these a try!!!  UPDATE 1/31/13:  I made these again, but because its too cold to grill I did them in the oven this time.  I think I prefer these grilled, but doing them in the oven works well too.  I put half the sauce on top of each chop, baked for 15 minutes.  Flipped over and put the other half of the sauce on and baked another 15 minutes.  I did pop them under the broiler for just a short time to caramelize the sauce on top.  Great recipe!

I added all the ingredients listed but added a little too much lemon juice by mistake but it was still tasty, just a little tangy. My husband gave them 8 out of 10 so I gave them 4 stars, which is probably a very generous rating.  Will probably make again.

Very good but I also made a few changes the second time around.  I had to double the recipe for 4 pork chops.  I omitted the oil, added 2 tbsp of OJ in place of lemon juice (what I had on hand) doubled the ketchup(4 tbsp) and added appx 2 tbsp of bbq sauce as well. userID:

Display Name:
Ms. gayle
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40314.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Please don't be fooled by the simplicity of the ingredients. This is impressive as is, I urge you to try it as written first. I needed quick meals to make for the elderly couple downstairs after the Mrs got out of the hospital.  I saw this and said "what could be simpler". I am truly not a huge pork fan. I used pork steaks. I trippled the sauce using proportion as stated. I did add 1T finely chopped onion and slivered sun dried tomato's, (the bagged kind, not oil packed) poured half into the glass dish and poured the other half over the tops and sides of the steaks. I put all in the fridge for a couple hours, to help the meat absorb more flavor. then put it in the oven. You could smell this all the way down the hall of my condo. Amazing! My steaks were about 3/4" thick and came out tender and perfect. The sauce is thinner but stirred and drizzled over garlic mashed potato's made it the perfect meal for a snowy 12 degree evening. I am making this again tomorrow for my daughter's family using boneless pork ribs! I cannot wait. I baked them at 375 for about 30 minutes..done to perfection. I am really looking forward to trying on chicken.
**UPDATE** When making this again, I used the Lea & Perrins "Thick Style" Worcestershire, it helped it to cling more to the meat and gave the sauce a bit more body.

text:
The marinade is delicious! The only thing I change is using pork blade steaks instead of pork chops, but that's just our meat preference.  The recipe amount is perfect for 2 pork steaks.  You'll want to double the sauce for sure if serving over rice! I let the pork steaks marinate w/ the sauce in the fridge for at least 3-4 hours before baking.  If I feel like it, I'll throw a clove or two of minced garlic in with the marinade.  I just baste with it's own cooking juices from the baking dish as there is always enough to do so. Cooking time for pork steaks is about 45 minutes at 375 degrees, turning once halfway through. They always come out a beautiful color and always very tender.  Leftovers are always even better the next day!  Thanks for this recipe!  :)

Display Name:
MESIII

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/498539.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading several reviews I decided to take some suggestions. I made this using 4 bone in chops, so to make sure I had enough sauce to put on the rice I tripled the recipe with the following changes: 1) 2 tbs olive oil 2) 3 tsp white vinegar instead of lemon juice 3) 3 tbs orange juice (could have added 1/4 c) 4) 3 cloves garlic chopped (would add more next time, my family loves garlic) 5) 1-2 tsp red pepper flakes I mixed the ingredients in a corningware dish and let it marinate for a few hours then cooked it at 350 for 15 minutes (covered) then flipped chops and cooked for and additional 10 minutes uncovered. I then broiled for for 3-5 minutes for a little char flavor. There was plenty of sauce for the rice and I could have actually added two more chops and had enough sauce. This recipe was a great base to jazz up several different ways. Thanks for all the inspiration!

None
text:
This turned out really good (best BBQ sauce I have ever made) but I'm gonna ding it a couple of stars for a couple of reasons. I don't know why it's called Marinated Baked Pork Chops when according to the recipe, you don't marinate the pork. I did (for about 12 hours) and the meat turned out super flavorful. Also, 60 minutes bake time for pork chops? Really? I did mine for 40 minutes (they were average thickness), and that was ample. Like I  say, the flavor was superb, but it wasn't quite right with pork chops. Next time I'll slow cook some pork tenderloin with the sauce in my crockpot, and shred it - it'll be awesome in sandwiches. Would work great with brisket too, I'm sure!

text:
I followed the advice of several other reviewers, and altered the recipe in several ways.  First, I marinated the chops for several hours before putting them in the oven.  I also only used 2 chops, but the whole recipe of marinade.  Next, I added some diced onion, approx 1 sm onion, and covered the dish with aluminum foil. Then I baked it for 30 mins on 350.  Then I removed the foil and spooned the marinade over the chops.  I baked it around 10 more mins at 450.  I served it with rice, broccoli, and apple sauce.  It was a great meal!!

I am having a pre-thanksgiving dinner, so I decided to try this recipe first before I actually make it for 10 people.  My husband and I loved it.  I'm a beginner in the kitchen and this was super fast, delicious and easy to prepare. I used 1/4 teaspoon for every 1 teaspoon of sauce used.  I skipped the brown sugar since I used Teriyaki sauce.

country:
None
text:
The inexpensive pork chops I used were tender and moist. Next time I'll probably double the amount of sauce and marinate the meat overnight in half of it, saving the rest to actually bake the chops in and perhaps use cider vinegar instead of lemon juice to add a bit more tang to the sauce.  I did drain the chops halfway through the cooking as others did.  An update to my initial post:  The leftovers made excellent Pork Fried Rice.  I cut up the pork and added it (along with the leftover sauce) to white rice that had been briefly sauteed with green onions.  Then pushed everything to the side and scrambled an egg.  Mixed all back in together and enjoyed my lunch.

5

text:
The one hour in the oven was a little long so mine came out a little on the dry side.  But the family loved it!  Can't wait to try it again.....but decrease the baking time.  I also didn't have any Worcestershire Sauce so I replaced it with Oyster Sauce.

Something else I did with the leftovers the next night:  marinated pork fried rice.  I just put the leftovers in the food processor with a litle soy sauce and shredded them.  Then I lightly fried it in a pan with some vegetable oil.  Added the cooked rice and a little more soy sauce until the rice was light brownish.  Mixed it all up and served it with broccoli.  Delicious!

text:
I used thin-cut, boneless pork chops and only cooked them for 15 minutes on each side, and they came out tough. (I doubled the sauce, so the chops were almost completely covered.) If I make this again, I will try marinating the chops in the mixture for a couple of hours. Beware, when I opened the oven door after the second 15 minutes, the oil in the sauce was spattering everywhere -- even on my arms as I removed it from the oven. So I'll either skip or reduce the oil next time! I don't know how to describe the flavor, but it's not too sweet, not too ketchup-y -- somehow the ingredients all blend into a good flavor (despite an unusual aroma while baking). It's an easy weeknight dinner. Thank you, Kim!

I followed this recipe as is no changes, but I only had two,  1 1/2 inch thick pork chops to use. This was just enough sauce, so as one poster pointed out - if you're looking for sauce, you might want to consider upping the sauce ingredients.
Ok, ok...  the only 'changes' were in the cooking time and way - I covered the casserole dish with foil for the first 30 minutes and cooked it slow on 310F (I rent and the oven is wonky, runs on the high-side)  The meat was so tender and juicy and the flavour was delicious!
The hubs gobbled it up and made a sad face when I told him there wasn't any for seconds.
We will make this again, and again, and again....
Thanks poster!!

I will definitely make this again.  The sauce is amazing, but I will double the sauce next  time because it wasn't enough for my taste (I like to have extra for the rice & meat dipping). I had a bit of xtra sauce in the pan, but there was a lot of grease in it. I am still a beginner cook (4 mo.),  but I have learned a lot on this site. So that said, I think Ill try these changes next time.  Sear the chops first to get out some of the grease before baking.  Perhaps this will also keep the chops juicier (please post if you know how to keep pork chops tender & juicy). Perhaps its the quality of the meat?  Anyway, I will also double the sauce recipe, put a smaller amount directly on the chops and heat the remaining sauce in a pot.  Definitely give this recipe a try. Four stars because of the changes I will make to match our liking, but very yummy!

text:
This is one of our favorites; however, 1 hour is  too long.  I bake it  for about 22 minutes on the first side,  20 on the 2nd, otherwise  the chops are too dry.  I also cover it with foil until the last  4-5 minutes. AND I use 1 T oil instead of 2, and salt and pepper both sides before spreading the sauce on. Also, the sauce covers 2-3 chops, so you'd need to double it for 6. Very, very good!

text:
Wow, these are really good and so juicy!  The cooking time is way off, though, and the sauce is only enough for 2 pork chops (I only made 2, but kept the sauce ingredient amounts the same, so this wasn't an issue).  The first time I made these I followed the instructions, but only baked them for 30 min (15 min per side) - the flavor was good, but they were too dry and the sauce was oily.  The second time I made some changes: I reduced the oil to 1 TBSP, marinated the pork chops in the sauce for about an hour, and baked them covered for about 15 minutes per side.   I think this sauce would be good on chicken, too.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving five stars because this was really a great recipe for a marinade. I changed one thing for the recipe and that was olive oil for veggie oil (and I added cayenne pepper for personal preference) and I altered the cooking method. The title of this recipe is "Marinated Baked Pork Chops" and the chops really need to be marinated with ingredients listed. The directions as written for pork chops and how to cook them are subjective and need to be adapted to your meat - six pork chops can mean anything. And the ingredients for this recipe really either need to be marinated or need to simmered for flavor (the flavor is spectacular BTW). I recommend marinating. I had two 2" pork chops and marinated them for 24 hours in a zip top bag. I baked them at 350*  covered for 35 minutes and then finished them on the grill for about 10 minutes. My hubby said they were the best chops he ever had. They were moist, tender, and very flavorful, again FIVE stars for the ingredients in the recipe. I highly recommend this, just adjust to your meat so they do come out dry.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Easy, tasty recipe!  I wasn't blown away by the flavor, but it was good!  I omitted the worcestershire sauce (fish allergy), and doubled the sauce ingredients, and instead of doubling the oil used a "single" amt of oil and the same amount of rice vinegar.  I put half to 2/3 of the sauce on top of the chops in their baking dish, let sit in the fridge for a couple hours before cooking.  After cooking covered ~20 min, I scooped out the sauce/liquid in the pan and topped with the remaining sauce, and cooked uncovered another 10 min or so.  They were very good!  I think I will marinade in a bag next time though, to get the marinade all around the chops instead of just the top.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
689320
Display Name:
AUDREYWAITE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
48
favoritesCount:
199
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this recipe 4 stars because it tastes really great on its own, but even better with a few small changes.  My changes:  I double the sauce, but use 3 T rice vinegar instead of 3 T of the veggie oil - makes it a marinade.  I let the pork chops (1" center cut boneless) marinate all day and then pour the chops and all the sauce into a 9x13 pan.  I cook them uncovered at 350 until my meat thermometer measures 145 degrees.  Some days, this takes 30 minutes, sometimes only 25.  I don't turn them at all, just let them cook.  I then serve the chops with some of the sauce liquid over top - super yummy.  The rice vinegar gives this a kick that my husband loves.  The sauce liquid is also really good as gravy for mashed potatoes or over rice.  I don't make any extra sauce other than the initial doubled marinade.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 4 thick cut pork chops and made 4x the sauce (but not the oil).  I seasoned the chops with a bit of lemon pepper, made the sauce with an added small onion, finely chopped, put the chops in the pan with 1/2 the sauce over it.  Covered with foil, cooked 30 minutes, uncovered and then flipped the chops, added the other half of the sauce and cooked 30 minutes uncovered....yummm. Served over noodles. Hubby, who is not picky but doesn't give the "very good" comment much gave this a "very good".  The only change I may make would be to try a TBSP of corn starch in the sauce to thicken a bit so it will stick to the chops and noodles a bit more.  This was very easy and delicious.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I loved the flavor, however, either my pork chops were too thin (boneless at about 1 inch thick) or the cooking time far too long (and I took them out after 30 minutes) they were VERY dry...I should have taken them out at 20, but I thought I would attempt to follow the recipe.As it was, I took them out only half way through what the recipe said.  The sauce was amazing, I think I will make that to put over rice and meat any old time. I gave this three stars because there was not enough information regarding the type of pork chops..maybe if I had the bone-in ones that would have been different. I doubled the sauce and I did not use it all, but I did not turn them over half way through either. But good flavor!

text:
Excellent with these changes. For the sauce, use 1 tbsp of lemon juice and only 1 tbsp of oil per batch of sauce. 
Make 1 batch of sauce for every 2 pork chops. Marinate for at least an hour and reserve some sauce for basting. I only had to cook my 1 inch pork chops for 30 minutes covered, then 5 minutes in the broiler. They could have possibly even cooked slightly less and finished cooking while resting. Thanks for the recipe! Will definitely use again!

I had 8 pork loin chops and I tripled the ingredients including 2 cloves of garlic and marinated them for a couple of hours with half of the sauce. Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love it!  To make things easier on myself I just put the whole amount of sauce on them from the beginning and flipped halfway through.  Turns out great!  I put some "sazon" all purpose seasoning on mine for a little more zing.

Once you memorize this recipe it's really easy to just eyeball the ingredients and mix up however much marinade you want want.  

Tonight I'm trying lime juice instead of lemon juice, I'm sure it'll be great.

Update: Lemon juice works great btw.

I've made this a few times with chops and chicken breast.  It's really versatile.  

If you're low on worcestershire sauce you can sub fish sauce.  I wasn't low on worcestershire but I had some fish sauce sitting around that I'm trying to use up.  They substitute very nicely, it won't give you the exact same flavor but one that's equally good.

I've also added a few drops of sesame seed oil to the recipe sometimes, that compliments the ingredients well.

Also I always make double the amount of this.  

If you want to make it more kid friendly, just use extra ketchup without cutting back on anything else.  Kid's will never learn how to get accustomed to new flavors if they're never exposed to them, right?

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/582249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome. 
I marinated the pork chops in a store bought garlic lemon marinade for about an hour. I added a squirt of chili sauce to the sauce to give it the perfect kick.  I flash browned in a cast iron skillet (no more than 2 minutes on each side).  I poured half the sauce over the chops and covered with foil for the 30 minutes.  Took out the chops, turned them over and added the remaining sauce and put it back in the oven for 20 minutes.  Made more sauce with the no oil and replaced all the ketchup with chili sauce.  Steamed artichokes and green beans. After the 20 minutes I removed the chops and threw them back in uncovered on broil for 2 minutes.  I poured the remaining sauce lightly on the plate and placed the chops on while I prepared the rest of  the veggies. 
It turned out so tender. Definite go to!
I also baked sweet potatoes while preparing the chops and when I took them out before broil they were perfect.

text:
Very easy to make. My 1st time baking pork chops in the oven.

I added minced garlic & onions.
I also recommend using salt & pepper before marinating.
I marinated my thin boneless chops for about 6 hours and it still didn't marinate too well.
I recommend quadrupling the sauce.

I covered my chops for the 1st 30 minutes and they still came out dry.  I highly recommend the baking time listed for thick pork chops.  Please make sure when using thin boneless chops, to not overcook or it will be extremely dry & tough.  My thickest cut came out normal, but my 2 other chops came out very dry.

text:
This recipe was ABSOLUTELY wonderful!!! It didn't smell too good at first, which had me a little worried, but the minute I dipped my finger in and stole a taste I couldn't wait to get the chops cooked so I could eat it!!! It was fantastic.  Just like everyone is saying, though, this does not make enough for six chops let alone four (which is how many I had).  I doubled this recipe for four chops and it seemed to be the perfect amount.  I would triple if you're going to be making six!!! But WELL worth it and more than simple to make!

This was a hit! My boyfriend said they were the best pork chops I've ever made! I doubled the recipe for a serving of six chops. I marinated both sides of the chops for about an hours. I followed another's suggestion and added sliced onions. Covered in foil for 30mins. Removed from oven and drained the extra juice. Turned chops over, added more sauce and baked uncovered for 30 mins. These chops were tender and juicy!

None
country:
None
text:
An excellent and easy recipe. Made some small preparation changes. First, I doubled the recipe. Making it as is seemed to be not enough for the chops I had. I also put the chops into the sauce before cooking them for about an hour. Helped keep some extra moisture. Then, while it was cooking, I caramelized some onions and added them during when I flipped over the chops. Extremely tasty, simple and drool worthy. Will be making this again!

One bite and my eat- in -silence husband said, smiling, "Thanks, Hon. These are really good!" Will be making these again! I would strongly advise doubling the recipe for the sauce because it is so good. The meat is super tender and moist. I used boneless center-cut chops, so I shortened the time, and like many reviewers, would also recommend broiling for a couple of minutes to allow the sauce to adhere to the meat better.  Thank you, Kim! It's gonna be a good, good night! LOL

city:

country:
None
text:
Loved it!  Personally, I like a lot of sauce, especially if serving with rice which I did.  So I tripled the sauce and marinated 6 center cut chops for a few hours in some of it, saving the rest in the fridge for later.  I did sub sesame oil for veg oil, but only doubled that measurement.  I put the chops (including marinade) into a glass baking dish and baked them as directed, though I did cover them for the first 30 mins.  Then turned them (had to spoon off some grease/oil at that point), poured on the remaining sauce which I had simmered on the stove top and finished them off uncovered.  I did the broil trick for the last 5 mins to tack up the sauce but mine hadn't actually run off like others mentioned.  Maybe because I added the reserved portion later.  Chops were perfectly cooked, so tender, and the sauce was fabulous!  Even my fussy boyfriend really liked it.  That's saying something because he leans more toward bland foods and this meal is absolutely NOT "bland".  Thanks for sharing!  Yummy :)

Wow, this was surprisingly easy and it tasted delicious.  I've never even attempted making something like this, but you really can't go wrong.    I doubled the recipe for the sauce (minus doubling the extra sugar) and it was still yummy.  I also forgot that I wanted to boil/simmer the sauce first to make it a little thicker when the pork chop was cooking for the first half hour and when I checked on it the sauce had run off the chop. country:

text:
I don't care for pork chops that much, but these are very good.  I did marinate for about 5 hours and also tripled the sauce.  The only problem was that I found the sauce to be a bit thin. The last 15 minutes of baking time I took the chops out of the sauce, poured the sauce into a small pot and thickened it with cornstarch.  Simmered for a couple of minutes on top of the stove until it thickened. Then returned it to the original baking dish and poured the sauce over the chops and put it back in the oven for another 15 minutes.  It turned out perfect.  I will try it in the slow cooker next time which should really tenderize the chops. It went really good with "onion rice and pea and crab salad" also from this site.  This has definitely got to be the best place to find great recipes.

text:
My family raved about these pork chops and it's all about the sauce! I definitely will double the sauce recipe, since the amount was not enough for six boneless chops, plus we wanted extra for dipping! Next time I will put the pork chops on a drip pan and not a baking pan. As the pork chops baked, they sat in a lot of drippings and the the sauce started getting watery. I put the done chops on a different pan and put them under the broiler for a couple of minutes so the remaining sauce would get slightly carmelized. SO GOOD!

Tasty!!  Made these for dinner tonight, but since I was only cooking for hubby and I, cut the recipe in half (only used 2 chops).  I found the 'sauce' amount to be plenty.  I did mince a garlic clove into it and opted to use sesame oil instead of veg oil (nice complement). Baked covered for 30min, then uncovered for 10, perfect!  Juicy and moist, thanks!

text:
We enjoyed the flavor and our pork chops were very tender. I doubled the marinade recipe, marinated the chops overnight in half. I baked them uncovered. First for 15 minutes  in the marinade they had sat in overnight. Then poured that off and basted with the other half and baked 15 more minutes. The sauce thickened and stuck to the pork just fine. Easy and delicious!

text:
Really good marinade. I made it exactly as stated but had no lemon juice...I also cooked for two so I cooked it for 20 minutes on one side and 15 on another. Really good flavor with stuff I had on hand.

Made this again with lemon juice...I make the marinade in a ziplock bag and swish it together with my fingers then put the (2, 1.5-2 inch thick boneless chops) in the bag and marinade it for 4-5 hours. I bake as stated above and it is soooo juicy and has really great flavor! Thanks for this recipe!!!!

text:
This was liked by the whole family.  I chopped an onion and added it to the sauce.  Next time I might sautee it 5-10 minutes first.  I tripled the recipe for 6 good-size chops and had plenty of sauce.  One hour is way too much cooking time.  Mine were more than ready after 45 minutes.  One problem was that so much liquid came out of the meat, the sauce got a lot thinner than I wanted/expected.  Any fixes for this?  I tried pouring off all the sauce into a saucepot at the end and cooking it down, which helped some but everyone wanted to eat already.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these for a church dinner, and they were a big hit! But because i had t make them before church, and such a large quantity, i changed the cooing instructions up some. I used about 30 boneless chops, and put them in a turkey sized oven bag in my big roaster. On each layer, i poured a little bit of the sauce. Then when I had them all in, i poured the rest of the sauce in. I let them sit overnight in the fridge, and this morning i turned the bag over to let the sauce go ther other way. I cut my six slits in the bag and baked them for about an hour and a half at 350. They cooked perfectly, but the sauce ended up mixing with the juice. This made them less saucy, ut the shops themselves were full of flavor. Everyone enjoyed them though, and I even got a thumbs up from my father-in-law, who is usually skeptical about new things. The only thing was.. I didn't like them too much! But I was the only one.

I thought the flavor of the marinade was excellent. Seeing the other reviewer's comments about the runniness, I substituted honey for the sugar and it thickened it up some. I also added a sprinkling of Italian seasonings to the top while baking. They complemented the flavor nicely and made up for the water from the chops dilluting the marinade. I will definitely make this again, but next time I think I will follow another reviewer's advice to pan sear them prior to baking.

text:
This was very good!  I had 4 boneless pork chops and marinated them for 2 1/2 hrs in sauce as stated (minus 1/2 T. oil) plus 1 tsp garlic powder.  While I put that marinade together in one ziploc bag, I also put together another thing of sauce in another ziploc bag and refridgerated that along w/ the marinating pork chops and sauce.  Then when time to bake, I used the fresh sauce to put on according to recipe directions.  Only needed to bake about 10-15 min each side as my porkchops were only about 1/2 in thick.

These were really good.  Extremley tender and well flavored.  I used center cut bone in chops, so my cook time was about an hour and fifteen minutes.  I added some minced garlic to the marinade [I add fresh garlic to everything but my desserts hehe].  I also covered the chops in the marinade and wrapped them in saran rap in the fridge for about an hour before cooking.  I also doubled the marinade so I could add more during cooking.  All and all a really good weeknight recipe.

GOOD RECIPE- BUT it needs some changes!

userID:
1366722
Display Name:
TRIMMIE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just fixed this recipe today.  Very good, a solid 4.  I altered it a bit and used others' tips as well.  Coated the chops with a little flour, seasoned salt and pepper and seared it on a skillet first.  Layed the chops on a bed of onions then sprinkled a touch of lemon juice, ginger and cinnamon on top then the sauce.  To the sauce I added 1 Tbsp honey, 1 Tbsp apple juice, 1 tsp apple cider vinegar, pinch of minced garlic and 2 dashes of tobasco.  Instead of using 2 Tbsp ketchup I used 1 Tbsp ketchup and 1 Tbsp tangy barbecue sauce.  Do not use any oil,  it's not needed.  Next time I won't bake it as long.  Chops were still tender but could've been more tender.  I used 3, ~3/4" thick pork loin chops and baked them 15 min @ 325 then 5 min @ 350 on each side and used the amount of sauce for 6 chops.  The sauce is good, not like a barbecue or a sweet 'n sour but a nice blend of both.  Will try this recipe again and adjust the baking time : )

text:
It was great. The only thing different I did was that I used garlic infused olive oil in the sauce that I used to marinate the pork chops. I tripled the sauce so that I could have sauce to cook the pork chops and sauce to pork over the chops.  I marinated the pork chops for about 6 hours. with the sauce.  It took about 30 minutes to cook.  I also broiled them a bit.  I served them with corn on the cob and garlic mashed potatoes.  There wasn't a drop of food left on the plate.  Definitely a keeper.

text:
It was a little dry, but I did like the sauce. I let the chops soak in buttermilk for a few hours. Doubled the sauce recipe. Sauced the chops and baked covered for 30 minutes, flipped chops and cook for another 20 minutes (still covered). I then drained liquid and added remaining sauce and broiled it for about 8 minutes (uncovered). I let it rest for about 10 minutes. I wouldn't mind using the sauce recipe again for something else.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4566479.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I soaked the EASILY 1 1/2 inch thick bone-in chops in the marinade over night.  Used a thermometer set to 145 and covered the dish the chops were in the first 20 minutes at 350.  Then, I pulled out the chops, drained the liquid from the bottom of the dish and put the chops back and baked 15-20 more uncovered at 350.  Meanwhile, I saved some sauce aside from the sauce I made for the marinade and in the last 1/2 hour reduced it in a saucepan to thicken.  Used that thickened sauce to pour over over the finished 145 degree chops.  Now in the dinner rotation.  Thank you, Kim.

My husband really doesn't love pork chops but he gave this easy recipe 5 stars. I tripled  the sauce with the exception of the oil. I only used 1 TBSP olive oil total. We will have this again.

userID:
8475220
Display Name:
pjb3655
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
62
favoritesCount:
507
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6798480.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe as written other than making extra sauce. I did change the cooking method a bit. I heated a cast iron skilled (oiled) in the oven, and put the pork chops directly on the skillet, then poured some sauce over. I used a meat thermometer as my chops were thick. I also covered the chops for the first part of cooking Flipped them at about 70 degrees and added more sauce. The first side was seared so it made broiling less of an issue. I finished them to 145, pulled them out to rest and put the skillet on the stove. I had a bit of sauce left over so I added that to the pan and reduced it a bit. Hubs approved of the meal. I think a meat thermometer is key with chops or any loin meat. Pork is so lean these days that overcooking ensures a tough product. I served the chops with mashed potatoes and broccoli.

country:

text:
EASY - Good for family.  Made to the recipe but with double the sauce as suggested.   Tented the pan with foil for the first 30 minutes in the oven.  Drained out the excess liquid then  flipped the chops over and spread on more sauce for the remainder of the bake time.  Then broiled for 3 mins with the remaining sauce on top to finish......  DH thought the sauce was "too much" flavour but I thought it was exactly right for pork.  Very easy to make, ingredients on hand......used 1 inch pork loin chops, bone in.  Time was fine, meat stayed moist and tender.  Served with Basmati rice and buttered corn.   Will make again.  Can't give 4.5 stars to split the difference with DH, so I gave 4 .

text:
I have made this several times in the last couple of years since finding it and always tastes great! I always double or triple the recipe and let t marinade. I also took a tip from someone else by only cooking them for 15-20 mins and using Tin foil for half the time and put it on broil for the last 5 minutes. The pork chops always come and tender this way and never dry. This is a keeper! My family loves it! I usually serve with whole grain rice or mashed potatoes. A great sauce over the potatoes as well!

This marinade is good but it is a bit thin (so I used 3 vs. 2 TBSP of brown sugar) and I made two batches.  I used one batch as a marinade on the chops, about 4 hours. Last note:  I only had 3 bone in chops, in my opinion, was just enough marinade , more chops will need more marinade.

text:
We loved this!!  At the end of baking I put more sauce on top and broiled them until it carmelized. They were awesome!!!  You can add more brown sugar for this and it will carmalize quicker. I took them out of liquid and onto a different pan prior to broiling. They were still tender and delicious!  Be sure to poke holes on both sides of chops before baking to allow for marinade to get into them.
Review:

dateLastModified:

userID:
11036879
Display Name:
Kae 
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5051402.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This sauce was so simple to make and was just right for my family's taste. Instead of baking, I broiled the chops. I put the sauce on one side, put it sauce side down in the pan and added sauce to the other side. I broiled it on HI four inches from the broiler for five minutes, then turned them, brushed on more sauce ( I doubled the recipe ) on the top side and broiled again on Hi for 5 minutes. I did this three times and then reduced the broiler to Lo setting and continued rotating two more times until the juices ran clear. The total cook  time was about 30 minutes, but the time will probably depend on how thick your chops are. They came out moist and flavorful and there was enough sauce left to add to the chops before serving or to use with rice as a side.  I will definitely use this again, maybe on the grill next time!
Review:

text:
The recommended temperature for pork chops was reduced to 145 degrees, but added a 3 minute rest time. I have used this new information and has resulted in a chop that is not as tough. 
"The USDA says the change does not apply to ground meats, including beef, veal, lamb, and pork, which should be cooked to 160 degrees. The safe cooking temperature for all poultry products, including chicken and turkey, remains 165 degrees Fahrenheit."

text:
These were really tasty. I used the pork chops I had on hand (4 really thin chops) and used the same measurements for the sauce. Instead of bushing the sauce on and adding it to the dish when baking, I opted to marinade my chops in the sauce for about 6 hours. At dinner time, I threw the chops and sauce into a Pyrex and baked for 20 minutes (on account of the thinness of the chops). They were perfect- flavorful and tender. I don't usually love pork, but I cleaned my plate for these! Thanks for a great and simple recipe!

text:
After reading some of the reviews, I made this but used 1/2c brown sugar, 1/2c ketchup, and 1/4c of everything else, except lemon juice I used about 1/3 of the quarter - cup measure, trying to duplicate the exact recipe with more sauce,  without having to measure tons of tablespoons.  It was very tasty, if a little sweet, and there was plenty of sauce. Might cut the brown sugar down next time. Also, I think I would reduce the sauce a bit in a pan after cooking the chops. My husband was thrilled because the chops stayed moist - he hates dry pork. Served over rice with veggies on the side. Will definitely use this recipe again!

text:
I made these for the first time last night. Using other reviewers' suggestions, I added a little jarred garlic to the sauce. I used four boneless  pork loin chops, which were approximately 1" thick. We have a good-size toaster oven and I baked the chops in it for 28 minutes total. I usually overcook pork, but not this time! My husband said they were cooked perfectly! I will make these again...doubling the sauce; using half as an actual marinade (for at least an hour) and the remainder to cook with.

text:
So when reading recipes on here, I always ALWAYS look at the critical reviews. I'm glad I did, because this recipe as it is was not enough for 6 pork chops. Maybe the small thin ones? But not the larger butterfly ones (and especially not the bone in ones). I added some garlic and some teriyaki sauce to it, so it has a really nice rich flavor. It's a good quick marinade, so it's in the fridge for about an hour (give or take) before its grilled.

userID:
4556221
Display Name:
Jeannie K

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5786094.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The taste of the sauce was good, not amazing. A bit too sweet. I bought fairly thick loin pork chops. An hour at 350 is way too long. I checked them and removed them after 45 minutes and they were still very well done. The days of cooking pork that long are, fortunately, over. The author does state to cook to a temp of 145. After 45 mins, mine were over 160 even with less oven time. I like the fact that there is no flour or corn starch as I prefer to keep meals low carb. However, in the oven this sauce does not reduce and the chops are not really browned at all just cooked. 
If I make again , I would reduce the sugar and brown the chops first and cook the whole dish stove top  to reduce  the sauce and make it a little more of a glaze. I would remove the chops when cooked to medium or slightly less and continue to cook the sauce until reduced to more if a richer state. 
I did as other reviewers suggested make more sauce. I served  Shirataki noodles.   I try to follow a recipe as written, when making for the first time. Overall a good start but needs some adjustment. 
Thank you for sharing as it is always fun to try something different.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
I have to say that initially I was very leery in making this marinade...but I was desperate not to have plain 'ol pork chops last night. I was pleasantly surprised! 

I doubled the recipe and I'm glad I did because it was just enough (I'm a sauce lover). I adjusted the cooking time just a bit because I only had two pork chops and they were  1 1/2 inches thick and bone in.  For the final stage of cooking, I poured on about 2 tbsp of marinade on top of each chop and put them under the broiler till the sauce caramelized. :)

We ate the chops with mashed sweet potatoes. It was a great meal and thanks for sharing your easy but delicious recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
jennifersheremetta
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/460163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Suggestions:
salt and pepper then add the sauce.
place on foil lined pan and then use a foil tent to keep moist.

The ONLY reason that this is getting a 4 star instead of a 5 is because the recipe doesn't call for salt and or pepper at all. SEASON SEASON SEASON SEASON!
Other than that , the ONLY change I made was that instead of an hour in the oven, I left them in for only about 50 minutes. I think had I left them in the extra 10 minutes, they would have started to get a little dry even with the foil tent.   
Now, from here on out, I followed the recipe to a "T" with the measurements.
I put the pork chops on a foil lined pan and then covered with foil to help keep them moist and boy oh boy did it work!!
Those chops came out tasting and looking so delicious!
NOTE:  if you are making more than 4 chops, I really think you need to increase the recipe for the sauce. 
I only made 2 chops  and what was left over didn't look like it would be enough for even 2 more really. 
So 2 - 3 chops = recipe is plenty
3 - 6 chops = double your recipe.

I made it for the first time with my family as the testers.  Everyone loved the chops!  I had 9 instead of the suggested 6 so by adding a little more of each of the marinade ingredients, it allowed for some dipping juice to be leftover.  The marinade has just the right amount of sweetness.  The chops were so juicy and delish.  I put aluminium foil over top for about 45 minutes and then took off the last 15 min.   Once they cooked for the full hour, I turned the broiler on low to give the tops of the chops a little crispness.  I will definitely makes these as a regular dish for my family.

text:
We really enjoyed these, and they were ready in no time. SUper easy!!  The sauce is nice touch... enough for basting 3 large chops.  My son and husband aren't big on sauce, so this one was perfect.  Just enough to flavor, not overloaded.  They enjoyed them.  I only gave it 4 stars because the cooking time was way off.  I had 1-1/4" chops. I cut the cooking time in half, and it still was too much. Just keep an eye on their temp the first time you try them.  Next time I would try 10, 10, and a couple minutes under the broiler  like other reviewers have recommended.  Definitely will make again. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I will definitely make this again. 
I did let it marinate for about an hour or so before cooking, in the marinade I also put minced garlic and a little minced onion with a large chunk of onion. I then dumped the entire thing (marinade and meet and onion) into the baking dish, covered with aluminum foil for 80% of the cook time, added more sauce when I removed the foil. I ended up making way too much sauce because I love having more rather than less.
Also, I used very thin pork chops, (discounted pack at Albertsons) so I only made enough for one meal as I don't think it would have reheated well. And I used organic farmer's market ketchup which has a very different taste than traditional Heinz. 
But delicious all around!

city:

country:
None
text:
I doubled the sauce recipe, halved the number of chops, and adjusted the cook time from one hour to 45 minutes which made this recipe pretty spectacular. The flavor is *marvelous* but I just didn't think the amount of sauce this recipe made was enough for three 1-in-thick pork chops, let alone six. I seasoned my three chops with salt and pepper, placed them in an 8x8 foil-lined metal pan, poured half the sauce on top, baked uncovered at 350 for 25 minutes, pulled them out and flipped them, poured the rest of the sauce on them, then popped them back in the oven for another 20 minutes. Overall, they turned out nice and juicy and the sauce was bomb.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The marinade was very good. My only complaint is that the recipe calls for an hour in the oven at 350F (30 minutes for each side) to cook the pork chop to 140-145F. I had very thick chops and I checked the temperature with a probe ten minutes early and the meat was well over 200F and the chops were not tender as a result. The author apparently doesn't know anything about heat transfer and I really should have questioned this timing. I would recommend 15 minutes one one side, turn the chops over, and then monitor the temperature closely until the meat reaches the desired temperature.

text:
Excellent!  I followed other recommendations and they came out very tender and juicy.  I tripled the soy, Worcestershire, lemon juice, brown sugar and ketchup.  Left the oil the same.  I marinated for 3 hours in 1/3 of the mixture.  When ready to bake I put them in a foil-lined pan, poured 1/3 sauce on top, and baked 20 minutes.  Turned them over and drained pan, poured remaining sauce on top and baked for an additional 20 minutes.  Then broiled for last 5 minutes.

userID:
1371349
Display Name:
Karen Martell Bishop
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2801015.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As other reviewers suggested, I tripled the sauce because I like it to coat the rice I serve with it too. I had five pretty thick cut boneless chops so I sliced them in half making ten thinner chops, another reason for tripling the sauce. I also added two large cloves of fresh minced garlic. I put HALF of the sauce in a gallon sized Ziploc bag with the ten thin sliced chops, and saved the remainder of the sauce to pour over the chops when I flipped them in the oven.  I squished the air out of the bag and squished the chops around to coat well.  I marinated them over night to have for dinner the next night.  I poured the chops with the marinade in the 9x13 dish and cooked at 350 for 30 minutes.  Then I flipped them over and poured the reserved marinade over the top of the chops and continued to cook for another 28 minutes while I cooked the Asian Coconut Rice (also from this site), and steamed broccoli.  When they were done, I took them out and let them sit for 2-3 minutes.  These were AWESOME over the rice with all that yummy gooey sauce!  Will definitely make this again.

text:
I cook for a camp of 20 - 25 blokes in the Northern Territory, Australia. They really liked this - I cooked way more chops than I needed to and there was only one left!
I quadrupled the sauce, poured it over the chops in the trays and let it sit for an hour before I covered and cooked them (turned once halfway). I also added some slices of green cooking apples throughout the tray which baked nicely.
Next time I might add a bit of 'bite' like sweet chilli or something for another level to the flavours. Great sauce!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These were good.  After reading some of the other reviews, I knew I was going to have to at minimum double the recipe for the sauce, so I did that, but did not add any additional oil and there was barely enough to cover my 4 pork chops.  As it cooked, it became very runny and didn't stick to the chops.  My chops were a little on the thinner side, so I tried cooking for 20 min on each side, but I think that was still too long since they were a little dry.  The sauce had great flavor but it was the consistency of water.  I think next time I will marinade the chops all day and then add some additional ketchup and brown sugar to hopefully thicken the sauce a bit.  Another option would be to use the broiler for a few minutes, like several others did.

text:
We are not big on pork chops, however with the price of beef, we're eating pork chops and this recipe is excellent! My wife and I thought the mix of ingredients seemed odd, but it works great! We used the recipe the 1st time exactly as written, in the oven, was wonderful. We used the sauce on 3 pork chops, obviously applying the sauce much more generously then the recipe calls for. The 2nd time we marinated the 3 pork chops for 6 hours in half the sauce and then cooked them on the bbq. I applied some of the remaining sauce as I cooked and the remainder I put on the table to add to our rice or pork! A simple recipe that works, try it....well worth it!

text:
The sauce is very tasty. I read that vinegar can be used as a substitution for lemon juice. I used half a teaspoon of rice vinegar.  Also, I only had 4 pork chops that were maybe an inch thick. I put them in for 30 min. then flipped them, and after 10 more minutes, I decided to take them out.  They were very tender  and not dry! Next time I think I'll flip after 15 minutes and cook for another 15 so they will be more moist. 

Also, I had just enough sauce for 4 chops. If I had more I would need more sauce.

text:
Made as written, I would give 4 stars.  I took other reviewer's suggestions on doubling the recipe - glad I did!  Also, I replaced the ketchup with chili sauce.  The only other (and big) change I made was I added 2 envelopes of onion soup - glad I did that too! It enhanced the flavor nicely.  I will definitely make this again, but will try to allow time for marinading the meat in the recipe first.  It was fine without, but the flavor definitely had not penetrated the meat, and was limited to the outside.  I will try this with chicken too!

text:
Delicious. Not quite enough marinade for 6 chops unless you're extremely sparing. I recommend 4 or at most 5 porkchops instead of the 6 in the recipe. I also recommend pinning the porkchops before marinating them, to get the flavour more fully inside. Otherwise you're left with a delicious exterior with a moist but flavourless interior.
