Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-01-10T10:12:51.3
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
17249851
Display Name:
guardianm3
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
24
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the recipe, I looked at the reviews.  I read so many suggestions and decided on a marinade variation that another reviewer had posted.  The marinade I used was 2 Tbsp of olive oil, 4 Tbsp of Worcestershire sauce, 4 Tbsp of lemon juice, 6 Tbsp of brown sugar, 3 Tbsp of ketchup, 3 cloves of garlic 4 Tbsp of vinegar.  I omitted the soy sauce since I didnt have any.  I marinated the boneless pork chops (1 thick and eight of them) for about six hours I cut up two small onions and layered one of them on the bottom of a 13 x 9 pan.  I put on the pork chops and the marinade. Put the other onion on top. I covered it with aluminum foil. Cooked it at 350 and I flipped the pork chops over every fifteen minutes.  I did that because so many people said that their pork chops came out so dry.  It did take an hour for my pork chops to be done.  I did try to broil the pork chops for the last 10 minutes (doing both sides of the chops); since many people said that, this would thicken up the sauce.  It didnt work which was fine, since it was tasty anyway.   I paired it with boiled potatoes and Green Bean Casserole.   

I invited my family to come and try this new recipe with me.  Okay, okay, I admit, I was using them as taste-testers.  My family liked this recipe, as did I.  A few minor things that I would change from what my family suggested.  First, I would to make a sauce from the leftover juice.  I would drain it and reduce it 50% (which I did read as a suggestion from someon

Amazingly, I had every ingredient except lemon juice so substituted orange juice and doubled the sauce. So tender and yummy. Enough sauce remaining to use as dip for the pork. In my favorites!!

text:
With just a little tweaking this is easily a five star recipe! After reading other reviews I doubled the recipe, used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. I still used the ketchup but added a teaspoon of garlic chili sauce and two teaspoons of minced garlic. I used low-sodium soy sauce so I could add a few drops of fish sauce. It balanced the flavor to near-savory perfection! I also covered the chops to retain moisture~ I will definately do this again!!! Would be a great grilling sauce.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1210239.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight in the convection toaster oven in a tray with a rack in it and it was excellent. I used the "sauce" more like a baste and not a "sauce" even though you can use it as such as in the video. I just a coated the top. This basically helps seal in juices and giving it a chance to brown more. It aso helps from having the chops boil in the sauce, which I don't like. I first poked my chops all over with a fork to get the flavors inside. I only topped the chops and turned and top coated the other side halfway through cooking time. I like a little more caramelization so I broiled each side for 5 mins, 10 mins before the end time. Delicious.

country:
None
text:
I tried the mix as directed, and liked it. I then tried it another way. I adjusted the amounts of the mix ingredients, with the exception of the oil. 2 tbsp of soy, 2 tbsp oil, 2 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 1/2 tsp lemon juice, 3 tbsp brown sugar, 3 tbsp ketchup. By doing this, it increases the thickness of the sauce, and reduced the temperature to 275 for 20 minutes per side for thinner chops. They turned out very well.

These chops were delicious!  Very flavorful and juicy!  I didn't change any of the ingredients but I did bake them at 325 for 25 minutes in my convection oven (2X). country:
None
text:
The thickness of the chops was NOT specified. Nor was it specified bone-in or boneless. I used 1.5 inch thick bone-in chops, and I quadrupled all the ingredients (except for the sugar and the oil). I had six chops, and that was more than enough sauce.  It was a thin sauce.  I baked them for 30 minutes and they were almost done. I put more sauce on and let them bake for about 5 more minutes. I did NOT turn them over. They were pretty good.  I think it is an easy recipe. I probably could have merely doubled the sauce instead of quadrupling it.  I would make this again.

text:
An easy-to-prepare and tasty recipe. I made the sauce as indicated, only adding chopped onion before putting the chops in the oven. Cooking pork chops for an hour seemed too long, so I used a thermometer, and they were done in just over 30 minutes. I took the advice of several reviewers and after the cooking time, drained most of the juice and broiled the chops for a few minutes. A good meal.

country:
None
text:
I've made this three times now and each time I was told by my family and best friend how delicious it was. I use kosher salt and cracked black pepper to season the thick center cut chops I use. I also multiply the sauce times 6...trust me, you will want the extra to add when you plate your dinner. Separate the sauce in two bowls so the one you may want for the table isn't contaminated by raw pork if you use a brush to baste.

text:
Delicious! I used 3 thick boneless pork chops and took the advice of other reviewers and doubled the marinade. I used half to marinate the chops for a few hours prior to baking. I baked at 375 for 15-20 minutes per side, added a bit more marinade after I turned them and then broiled for 3 minutes at the very end. I added the last bit of marinade right before broiling. The chops turned out perfectly! My husband said he thought they were the best chops I ever made. Can't wait to make this again!

text:
Tried this recipe for dinner & it came out pretty good. My kids wouldn't eat it but they don't eat anything haha but hubby & I thought it was good. I did double the marinade recipe & put a little over half in a bag with the 4 boneless pork chops then I used our vacuum sealer to seal it & put it in the fridge for 4 hours. I then used the remainder of the sauce to brush on the top of the pork chops half way through the cook time & the rest my husband used to dunk his chops in.(This sauce was not used on the raw pork chops, it was placed in a separate dish once made & placed in the fridge.)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great hit with me and my boyfriend. I made it tonight and he cleared his plate completely. 
I gave it 4 stars because I found the sauce to be too watery once cooked, and I had to add a few things to make the sauce taste better .
I added 1tbsp apple juice, 3 garlic cloves (crushed), 1 tbsp black pepper, 1 tbsp ACV and one half an onion grated. 

Next time I will be adding 1 or 2 tablespoons of corn starch or flour to help it thicken up a bit. Will be marinating over night as well. 

All in all a great recipe that is easy to make and the sauce is very easy to adjust to your personal preference.

text:
I used this marinade for pork and chicken and it is awesome. I personally used 1 tbs of brown sugar instead of 2 because 2 was a bit sweet. Also, I found that the recipe, as written, only worked for 2 pork chops or about 6 chicken tenderloins, so I recommend doubling or tripling the ingredients for any more than that. Lastly, I let the meat marinate in the sauce overnight--awesome! The picture is last night's dinner--chicken, carrots, and onion all baked in the sauce, rice and peas on the side. Enjoy!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was excellent but the cook time and measurements for the sauce are way off. I only baked them for 15 minutes on each side, and the internal temperature was 170 when I took them out. They were dry and a bit tough, but still tasted great (so I can only imagine how good they are when they are not over cooked!). I wanted to put them under the broiler to help the sauce stick (I had the same problem many others did with the sauce running off), but they were already over cooked. I only had enough sauce for 2 pork chops (I was only making 2, so that wasn't a problem). Next time I will reduce the oil to 1 TBSP, as others suggested. Hopefully this will make the sauce less runny. I will try reducing the cooking time and put under the broiler for the last 5 minutes.

I should have known. The cooking time was too long. I overcooked the chops. Though they were still tasty, they would have been far better if they hadn't been overcooked. I'm not blaming the recipe writer; each oven is different and ours usually cooks things faster than most. Next time, I'll turns the chops at 25 minutes and check them again at 45 minutes. country:
None
text:
IF YOU USE BONELESS pork chops, only cook for 20-30 minutes MAX! I had four boneless pork chops (thick cut but not too thick) and I cooked them for 30 minutes at 375 and that was too much. I doubled the recipe for the sauce and marinated it for about an hour. It tasted great except for the pork being over done.

I quadrupled the sauce like another reviewer and added white wine vinegar (I didn't have rice wine vinegar). I marinated the chops for 5 hours and cooked them on a raised grate. I reduced the marinade, but added another 1/4 of brown sugar and the pan drippings. It came out really good.

userID:
6378804
Display Name:
Aggie Houk
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1282829.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This marinade is delicious.but I did change it a bit, by adding a large min

ced garlic clove.I used 4 top loin chops w/o the bone.I used the sauce amounts for 6. I decided to marinate the chops,but when I put it all in a large Ziploc..the chops were't covered well. So I quickly made the recipe again,and dumped it in.Satisfied with that..Marinated 4.5 hours in the fridge. Then  just lifted each chop out by a fork,dripping with sauce,and put them on a wire rack,in an aluminum foil lined pan.I added a little water to the pan, so the drippings wouldn't burn.Cooked on 375 for 15 min.,flipped over, brushed on a bit more sauce and cooked 15 min. more.Turned oven to broil, with pan about 4 inches from coil for 2 min., to brown it a bit. Meat was tender and tasty. I heated the extra sauce and we drizzled it on our chop after we cut it up..Next time I will score the meat before marinating, so flavors will soak in.To the person who said, mix all other ingredients before oil, I find if you use your spoon for oil  before your catsup, the catsup just slides right  off the spoon,instead of holding on.

text:
I really liked this easy recipe!  Nice and tender chops, and all the ingredients were already in my pantry.  I used 4 pork chops and thought the sauce amount was just right.  Because they were not swimming in sauce, the little amount spread on each chop (about 1 T. each)bubbled and cooked into a nice glaze with no broiling needed.  Strange name though because the chops don't sit in a marinade for any length of time at all.  I will definitely line my pan with foil next time because my dish will soaking for awhile with burnt on sauce.

text:
I made these last evening for guests. They were WONDERFUL! Since I was cooking for a crowd, I used 11 chops. Others mentioned not having enough sauce. I tripled the amount, since I essentially was doubling the number of chops called for. It was just the right amount. I did decrease my baking time to 45 min. They were nice and moist, not at all dry. I think you need to factor in the thickness of the chop when determining baking time. This is definitely a keeper.

This recipe was quick and tasty and great because I already had all the ingredients on hand. I did leave out the vegetable oil and added a tiny bit of garlic and onion powders. I agree with others that the recipe is small--I made the full recipe and did just two ~6 oz boneless chops(could probably have done 3, but certainly not 6). Also, I only baked them 20 minutes on each side, and they were still a bit overcooked. If I had done 30 minutes on each side, they would have been charcoal.

text:
This recipe is awesome. It can be even better following the common advise of other reviwers: Double the amount of sauce adding garlic and minced onion;  marinate the meat for about half hour. You can cook these in the oven (uncovered for last 20 minutes) , the grill or your stove top. It is finger-licking goood!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The whole family loved this, including my son who typically opts to eats Grape Nuts cereal for dinner rather than eat anything my wife or I might make.  I did modify the recipe a bit. All ingredients which the recipe calls for 2 Tbl, I up to 3 Tbl, and 1 Tbl gets upped to 2 Tbl.  I use 2 tsp lemon juice, and add 2 Tbl Liquid Smoke (any variety is good).  I generally cook these on Sunday, and let them marinade before we head to church.  We get home 3 hours later right around dinner time, and the chops are ready to go.  Also, I generally cook these on the grill.  I get the best results on my grill cooking on high heat (lid open)3 minutes on each side then rotate (get those nice cross-hatched sear marks) for another 3 minutes on each side.  If you have a nice fatty chop, you do need to tend them vigilantly to avoid flare-ups that WILL char the meat.

text:
It was delicious my husband a very picky eater loved it!  Like everyone says I doubled the marinate and marinated the pork chops the whole day and added onions.  I used half the marinade and covered the pork chops with foil for 20 min then after I flipped and added the rest of the marinade for 15 min and the last 5 mins I broiled it!!  Wasn't satisfied with the sauce because it was to watery so I put the marinade I. A saucepan and added corn starch to make it nice and thick and then spread it back into the pork chops so it could be soaked in delicious marinade!

text:
Made this last night and the flavor was great. Only change I made was added a little more brown sugar and used EVOO. Both enhanced the flavor a little. Although this recipe calls for 6 chops, I used it on only 1. My chop was thick, though, about an inch but, following the cooking instructions, it came out perfect. Very tender and flavorful. I did marinate it before hand. Only complaint I have is the amount of sauce. Like I said, I only had one thick chop and used every bit of the sauce which was just enough. If I had more chops i would at least triple the recipe but, other than that, it was a perfect sauce.

Good tasting.  I marinated 5 1 inch chops for 5 hours.  Tripled the marinade sauce (A MUST).  Like Michele said, the sauce didn't stick very well to the chops.  My daughter ended up putting store bought bar-b-q sauce on them.  Covered them for the first 25 minutes with foil, took the foil off & flipped them & baked for 15 minutes, then broiled them for a few minutes.  Still came out a little dry.  Really have to pay attention when making pork chops.

text:
This was a good recipe. It'd be a great starting point as other reviews have mentioned because preparing it as is, the flavors of the dish don't really pop. Four star rating because it was pretty tasty considering the lack of fresh ingredients (I did use fresh lemon juice, though) or spices in the recipe. The meat was tender, but a had a bit of oil lingering from the pan (perhaps I did not trim the chops enough, maybe it was the addition of oil in the sauce). I served with a simple green salad. Overall, I would make this again with some tweaking of my own. Thanks for a new dinner recipe!

text:
What a super recipe!  I made this last night; the amount of sauce seemed a bit skimpy, so I decided last minute to double it.  I was so glad I did; since I don't use a meat thermometer, I baked the chops the full hour as directed, and they ended up on the dry side.  BUT--I had all that great sauce, so I gave everyone their own small bowl of sauce next to their dinner plates, and they totally loved dipping their meat into the sauce!  The taste was EXCELLENT!  The only thing I would change is the baking time--otherwise a great recipe and a real keeper!  This recipe's getting filed.  Thanks much!

text:
Nice sauce. Made as is with a little garlic powder and red pepper flakes.   It's thick and more like bbq sauce than a marinade.  Despite the sugar it's not overly sweet either.   I quadrupled the recipe for about 8 pork loin chops(make it 24 servings for easiest measuring), marinated for a few hours, saved some sauce back (not from the marinade) and cooked it down and served it over the top.  Very tasty.

text:
Made this tonight. It was good but we were not wowed. I decided to marinate the chops even though the recipe didn't specify a time for that. I intended to marinate for a couple of hours yesterday, but a different dinner plan arose so I ended up marinating 24 hours. Glad I did because the meat took on the flavors of the marinade quite nicely. The only other changes I made were, I used Red Wine Vinegar and EVOO like someone suggested. I upped the ingredient proportions with the exception of the chops. And finally, I cooked them in a lightly covered pan for 40 minutes straight and they was done. I only flipped them after they were cooked and let them set for about 5 minutes.

text:
I love this recipe because it's so quick and easy and uses ingredients that are always on hand. This sauce is really good! Although it was a little runny when it came out of the oven, I added a little flour and once it cooled down it thickened up a bit. Poured it over the chops and  mashed potatoes and we really enjoyed it. I used boneless pork chops that were just under an inch thick, baked at 350 15 min each side.

None
text:
Firstly, and I hate to be pedantic, but this is a glazed pork chop, not marinaded.  However, it is still good.  I had to make one adjustment due to food allergies.  I substituted 2 tablespoons of yellow mustard for the soy and Worcestershire sauces, and I added about a teaspoon of seasoned salt (Tony Chachere's).  The result was absolutely fantastic!  It's even better if you switch to broil during the last 5 to 10 minutes of the cooking as it caramelizes the glaze and pork.

My family LOVED these! I made the sauce as directed except I doubled everything but the oil. I used only 3 TB instead of 4 for a double recipe. I also used 1.5 lbs pork chops, which was 3 large chops plus one tiny one. They were about an inch thick and delicious. I marinated 3 pork chops (bone in) in the full amount of sauce for about 6 hours before we cooked them on the grill. We seared them on both sides over high heat before moving them to the cooler side of the grill to finish cooking. We poured the extra marinade over the chops as they were cooking. A++ AMAZING!! Next time I may add some cayenne pepper to spice it up a bit :)

These are really good! A nice change from the same old recipe. I served them with Baked Potato and Glazed Carrots. text:
These were pretty tasty chops!! I followed the other reviewers and broiled them for the last 4 minutes so the glaze covered the chops nicely. I didn't have soy sauce, so I used some mesquite marinade I had, which gave it a zing, and also only used 1/4 of the oil. Spread garlic and onion powder to season the meat, put in the oven for 40 minutes, covered for the first half, uncovered for the last, for 1-in pork chops and they turned out nice and soft! Thanks for a great recipe!!

None
text:
I really liked this. It used regular ingredients you are likely to have on hand and the pork chops did turn out moist. I tripled the recipe for 6 large thin cut boneless sirloin chops, and it was too much sauce, they were kind of swimming but we just fished them out and ate them. Thin boneless chops are hard to cook without overcooking or toughening/drying them out so this was a good test. I didn't expect this to be spicy or real tangy judging from the ingredients, so I slathered the pork chops with cracked black pepper and kosher salt on both sides before cooking. This was delicious with jalapeno/cheese bread and a tossed salad. Thank you for the recipe.

userID:
5889642
Display Name:
nvoong
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
4

65
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, but I made so many changes that I don't know if it's still the recipe.  Like many people recommended I doubled up on the sauce.  I didn't have any worcestershire sauce so I omitted it.  Substituted it with oyster sauce instead.  I also used balsamic vinegar instead of lemon juice (because it's what I had on hand).  I also mashed up half of a kiwi and mixed that into the marinade and added a good dose of sesame oil (didn't really measure it). I included the brown sugar and ketchup.  I pour all of the sauce over the pork chops and let them marinate for an hour (heard that kiwi can turn your meat to mush if left on too long).  Popped them in the oven for 30 minutes at 350 degrees, then turned the oven off and left the pork chops in the oven for an additional 15 minutes (don't know if it really made a difference).  They came out great.  I used bone-in, 1 inch thick pork chops and served with a side of baby bak choy and rice.

text:
I was in a pinch and found this recipe.  SO glad I did because I came back to find it today and now I am able to save it in my faves.  I think I quadrupled the recipe for four boneless chops and had a good amount leftover, so I would definitely recommend multiplying it for the amount you're making.  My family LOVED it. It's super easy and I almost always have the ingredients on hand and you don't have to marinate it that long (I tend to be last minute so this is perfect for me)  My fave part about it is that it makes almost like a glaze.  Delish!

text:
I use this recipe as a marinade for grilling pork chops. I marinade the pork for at least an hour, then grill. I reduce down the remaining marinade and brush on to the pork chops as they come off the grill. The pork chops (even thin ones) stay very moist!

It was a very good recipe! As I read the reviews after I made it I found someone else had the same good experience doing it the way I had, too, which was 17 mins on each side at 375 and adding sauce a third time and broiling for 3 mins to crisp the chop and glaze the sauce. I didnt have worcs, so I used steak sauce and a couple dashes red wine. Tripled the sauce and was exactly enough to brush 6 chops three times. Will make this a part of our regular menu!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 6 bone in 1" thick chops and needed to use two pyrex dishes to fit them all.  I did the recipe for 6 servings but ended up tripling the recipe.  I used half over them and covered them and baked them for 20 min on 375.  I then drained off the extra liquid and poured the other half on and then baked another 20 minutes.  I took the foil off and then broiled on low for 3 minutes to carmelize the sauce on top.  The whole family (3 kids ages 5-14 and my husband) love them!

text:
I made a double recipe of this sauce replacing the vegetable oil with 1 Tbps sesame oil and marinated a pork tenderloin and adding the sauce while it cooked. It turned out fabulous. I liked the base of this sauce so much that I decided to use it again in a shrimp stir fry. I once again used sesame oil instead of vegetable oil. I doubled the recipe and replaced one tsp of lemon juice with rice vinegar and I used a habanero ketchup for one of the tablespoons of ketchup. It gave the sauce a little kick, which was great in the stir fry. I love this sauce!

text:
The sauce is delicious!  This recipe makes just enough for 6 medium size pork chops.  The cooking time and temperature are off though.  I reduced the heat to 325 degrees and cooked the chops 20 minutes per side.  I also put them on a rack so that the sauce would form a glaze. I made extra sauce (minus the vegetable oil) to use as dip.  I placed the ingredients in a small saucepan and simmered them to dissolve the sugar, then cooled the sauce.

We loved these chops! I used the following suggestions that others posted... tripled the amount of sauce, added extra brown sugar to thicken, added rice vinegar, cut the oil in half, sprinkled w/garlic salt prior to pouring on the sauce, covered the dish for the 1st 30min of cooking. text:
I had some very thick pork chops-so I wanted to try something different. The "marinated pork chop" were great. I basically tripled the marinade, then "soaked"  the chops for about 2 hrs. Before baking I basted the tops-put in a 350 degree oven after an 1/2 hr.I turned the chops over and basted the top-let cook for another 1/2 hr. & they were done. I added some chile garlic sauce-not much, as it very spicy away they went

text:
I read previous reviews so I modified the recipe as advised. I tripled the recipe for the sauce and to me it seem to still be too thin.  The chops were really good and thankfully they weren't dry.  I also marinaded them in the sauce for about 90 minutes before cooking them in the oven.  I turned up the oven to 375 and only cooked them on each side for 15 minutes then I broiled them for 3 minutes before serving them.  I'll try this recipe again and next time I'll add some garlic salt to the chops before I put the marinade on them.

text:
Delicious!! I only cook for two, but I still doubled the recipe for the sauce (and only put in half the brown sugar), and spread the excess over the chops after serving. Also, if you can get your hands on "Curry Ketchup," use that instead of regular tomato ketchup. Or just add a teaspoon or so of curry powder when you're stirring the sauce. It really adds to the flavor!! My husband LOVED this recipe, and I will definitely be making it again!

Also great the next day cold chopped on a salad with sunflower seeds, mandarin oranges, chow mein noodles and the left over sauce as dressing.

text:
This recipe is great!  Even family members who are not pork lovers thought this was good.  What's even better is that the ingredients for this recipe are usually found in most kitchens.  No shopping necessary.  I did not change the ingredients at all except to double the sauce.  I only baked the chops for a total of 45 minutes, and I removed the foil for the last 15 minutes as others have stated.  The chops were moist and delicious.

text:
This recipe was a hit with my kids.  My 25 year old and 5 year old are extremely picky eaters, but both loved it, especially the 5 year old who said I just have to make this again. I followed another reviewer and increased the oven temp to 400 and shortened the cooking time.  For the last ten minutes, I broiled the chops five minutes on each side - the sauce carmelized, and they were absolutely wonderful.

text:
My boyfriend and I loved this recipe! I doubled the recipe because I wanted to let the pork chops marinade a bit. I didn't have any Worsteschire sauce, so I decided to leave that out. But I did dice up an onion and put that in. I substituted teriyaki sauce for the soy sauce. I also added some salt, pepper, and about a teaspoon of garlic powder. I let the chops marinade for an hour or two, baked them for 30 minutes, then threw on another coating of the sauce for another 30 minutes. The chops were great! Thank you for posting this one!

text:
These are really good. I use pork steaks instead of chops and they turn out tender. The marinate seems a little weird at first but when baked tastes so good on pork. I do drain off the liquid that accumulates when baking before I add the marinate the second time or they are too runny. I think I like them more than my family. Kind of reminds me of an asian flavor.

text:
I followed this recipe almost exactly...I added a touch of honey to the sauce and put sliced onion and fresh mushrooms to the bottom of the pan.  I also added sliced pineapple to give it a hawaiian kick...then I added the pork chops on top and topped it with more pineapple. I gave it a four star rating because of the fact that I changed the recipe.  While it wasn't horrible...it wasn't the best either.  Hubby liked it, but I don't think I'll make again.
